source.48a282de:
When analyzing data, I typically like to make sure I am thinking of a few questions.  Not having specific questions can be great because you can explore, but it can be easy for you to meander.  So **be purposeful in your questions that you are trying to answer and be sure to keep your your audience in mind.**

In this notebook, as part of the #chaiEDA group, we are acting on this task: https://www.kaggle.com/rohanrao/air-quality-data-in-india/tasks?taskId=1877 

**Task:** Unfortunately, your uncle's wife recently died due to severe air pollution. Your uncle is super rich and he misses his wife very much. He calls you, knowing that you love data. You pick up and he immediately says, "In 2 weeks, tell me which city to invest in to improve air pollution for the long run. You'll have the $ for 3 years. Then, if you are successful, I will give same amount for 2 more cities. Please provide a rough plan to convince me of which geographical city / area to focus on, why that city, briefly on how you will make improvements, and how you will track progress. Thanks." Then he says that he hopes your family is doing well and that he will call back in 15 days and then abruptly hangs up before you can say anything.

I will use the following tools to tell this story:

    1) Tableau -- I love using tableau to help discover the way in which I will tell a story
    2) Powerpoint -- Powerpoint gives me the flexibility to message things properly.  

In summary, I used **Tableau Desktop --> screenshots into Powerpoint --> storytelling in Powerpoint**.
source.4c684158: It looks like things have improved a lot in Hyderabad.  That is a relief.
source.d069f85e: I am using the same type of trend chart.  While I am not super thrilled about the formatting, I can see that Ahmedabad has benefitted the most from COVID.  I can also see the Delhi has improved a lot too.  (will add little light bulb later)
